oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Potential uses for bracken (Pteridium aquilinum (L.) Kuhn) in organic agrculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Donnelly, E
Robertson, J
Robinson, D
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Nutrient turnover
Root crops
Composting and manuring
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bracken is a weed species due to its toxic nature and adverse effects on agriculture and ecology. This poster reviews research into historical uses for fronds and litter harvested as part of organically approved control methods. The use of bracken as an over winter mulch reduced losses of nitrogen and potassium from bare soil and maintained soil temperatures. Bracken litter was found to be a viable biofuel, with a calorific value comparable to wood and low ash and alkali metal contents. The contents of frond ash were investigated, with high concentrations of potassium found giving them a value as organic fertiliser. The addition of frond ash to soil significantly increased clover growth and number of nodules. The addition of frond ash to soil significantly increased the yield of saleable main crop potatoes. These finding have shown that bracken has a value especially within organic agriculture.
